ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LICENSED HAWKERS
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for the Environment (a) how many licensed hawkers there were in Singapore as at 31st December, 1980; (b) how many more hawker-licences will be issued in 1981 ; (c) what are the present criteria for approving applications for such a licence; and (d) what types of stall are available to newly licensed hawkers.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for the Environment)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 25,889 licensed hawkers as at 31st December, 1980. 7,124 are housed in the Ministry of the Environment's food centres and markets, 15,501 are in food centres or markets managed by statutory boards, and 3,264 are operating in backlanes and streets.

    We do not set any quota for new licences. As there are enough hawkers, new licences are only issued on grounds of hardship and for cleared market stalls. In 1980, 325 persons were issued licences.

    The criteria for the issue of hawker licences under hardship cases are that the applicant must be a Singapore citizen, aged between 40 and 60 years and not gainfully employed. In addition, he must have dependants to support and a family income of less than $500 per month. There must

Column: 297

also be no licensed hawker among his immediate family members.

    Market produce stalls and stalls for the sale of piece and sundry goods are freely available to newly licensed hawkers. As we are short of cooked food stalls for the resiting of street hawkers, there will only be a limited number of these for new licensees.

CORPORATION DRIVE FOOD CENTRE
(Rebuilding of)


    2. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for the Environment when the Corporation Drive Food Centre will be rebuilt.

     Mr Chor Yeok Eng (for the Minister for the Environment)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Corporation Drive Food Centre was built in 1974. It is, therefore, not as modern as some of our new food centres. It is, however, still serviceable, and therefore it need not be rebuilt.

    When I replied to the Member for Jurong on a similar question last year, I said that we were aware that the roof for the cooked food centre was too low and that ventilation was poor. Further improvements were being studied.

    We are now finalizing our design proposals to raise the roof of the cooked food centre to improve ventilation. The proposals will be submitted shortly for approval of funds.

POLICE INVESTIGATION INTO CASE OF ABDUCTION
(Negligence)


    3. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in the case of the 10-year old girl who was alleged to have been abducted from Clementi Avenue to a flat in Toa Payoh and who was later set free by her abductors, why the police officer investigating the case, when he found no one in the said flat, did not pursue the matter further; and whether there was negligence on the

Column: 298

part of the police officer concerned, in view of the recent murder of two children in Toa Payoh.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the case mentioned by the hon. Member for Khe Bong has been under investigation by the Police before it was publicized in the press. These investigations, as to whether there was neglect of duty on the part of the police officer concerned in not pursuing the matter further than he did, have now reached the stage where the papers have been referred to the Attorney-General's Chambers.

    The Attorney-General has advised that facts relating to the alleged abduction of the 10-year old girl and the investigations following therefrom should not be disclosed publicly at this stage because the girl concerned will, in all probability, be a material witness at the trial of the three persons who have been charged with murdering two children in Toa Payoh. As the House will appreciate, the three accused face capital charges and the matter is sub judice and disclosures which may prejudice the outcome of their cases should be avoided.

    I am, nonetheless, aware that this case has generated considerable public interest. I wish to assure the House that a serious view has been taken of the matter and I will not hesitate to discipline any police officer who has been found guilty of dereliction of duty.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am quite satisfied with the answer given by the Minister for Home Affairs. But, nevertheless, I still wish to ask the Minister whether he can assure the House that such an incident will not be repeated in the future.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: The answer is yes. I will not only assure him but I will also take a very serious view of any dereliction of duty.

BRIBERY AND CRIMINAL BREACH OF TRUST
(Figures for 1980)


    4. Encik Wan Hussin Zoohri asked the Minister for Home Affairs, for the year 1980,

(a) how many persons were convicted on charges of (i) bribery, and (ii) criminal breach of trust; and (b) how many of such persons were professionals from (i) the public sector, and (ii) the private sector.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, from the figures supplied by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, 44 persons were convicted in court on charges of bribery in 1980. There was no professional from the public sector among them. However, there were three professionals from the private sector - two architects and an engineer.

    In the same year, 72 persons were convicted on charges of criminal breach of trust. Again, no professional from the public sector was involved but there were two from the private sector. One was an accountant and the other a lawyer.

MASS RAPID TRANSIT
(Study of proposal for all-bus system)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour whether it was necessary to conduct another study to assess the Hansen Review Team's proposal of an all-bus system; what is the purpose of Phase B of the Study, how long the Study will take and how much it will cost; and whether a firm decision on the MRT will be taken by Government after the Study.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, hon. Members will recall that the Hansen Team confidently concluded in its review last year that MRT is not inevitable. They claimed that a restructured all-bus system deploying a large number of high speed point-to-point express services would be able to cope with our transport needs well into the 1990s, if not forever. At the same time, such a bus system would provide a level of service comparable to the MRT, and at much lower costs.

    My Ministry's view is that the Hansen Team did not produce hard and convincing figures to back up their claims. Nor did they examine the operational implications of their all-bus system, such as how it would manage

Column: 300

with the large volumes of passenger boardings in the Central Area during the peak hours.

    For this reason, we have decided to undertake further quantitative work to establish, once and for all, whether an all-bus system will be able to cope. And if not, at which point in time an MRT would be needed.

    The Study will be conducted in two phases, Phase A and Phase B. In Phase A, which will take six months, the Hansen's allbus system will be developed and studied in detail to see if it can be implemented and, if so, with what consequences. Various claims made in support of the all-bus system will also be studied and tested. Phase A Study will cost some $2 1/2 million.

    Phase B Study, which will commence at the same time as Phase A Study, will take another two years after the completion of Phase A. It will do a refined analysis. It will also examine the basic MRT system established in Phase Ill Study of the Mass Transit Study to see how it compares with the all-bus system financially, economically and operationally. The cost of this Phase will only be known following the completion of Phase A, at which time a proposal detailing the scope of work to be carried out in Phase B will be submitted by the consultants.

    Being a gigantic and complex project with wide all-round implications, the decision to build the MRT can only be taken after all factors have been carefully considered. I am optimistic that the outcome of these studies will be conclusive enough to enable us to arrive at that decision.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Review Team's Study is to be conclusive enough, as the Hon. Minister has just pointed out, then could the Hon. Minister assure the House that this will be the final Study before a firm decision on the MRT can be arrived at?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have mentioned earlier and on some other occasions, transport considerations although important are not the only factors that will have to be considered in making a

Column: 301

decision. As I have mentioned earlier, Phase A Study will show us how an all-bus system will cope with the projected transport demand in the 1980s and in the 1990s. It will not look into the financial implications of the all-bus system nor will it look into the financial implications of the other alternative, which is the bus-rail system. This will be done in Phase B Study.

    Should the findings of Phase A show that the all-bus system cannot cope satisfactorily by the late 1980s or within this decade, obviously we will have to do some quick thinking and make a decision one way or the other. But if the Study concludes that an all-bus system will be able to manage up to the early 1990s, although it may not be beyond the century but the early 1990s or mid 1990s, then we can afford to defer the decision a little bit longer. But as I have mentioned earlier, if the conclusion that an all-bus system will not be able to handle the transport demand by the late 1980s, obviously we will have to make a decision quickly.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, it seems to me that the Government is uncertain about when to build the MRT. If that is the case, why did the Government conduct a feasibility study in 1979?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government is just as anxious as hon. Members in wanting to come to an early decision on this project. But we must not allow our decision-making process to be constrained by our own limitations in knowledge and experience in this field and by the narrowness of our own vision, especially in the context of Singapore with the small pool of talent that we have and the small physical size of the Republic, because if it is a mistake we will have to live with it. I have mentioned again and again in this House that it is very prudent to make sure that the maximum economic advantage is achieved and this could only be done with careful study and proper timing.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, the answer is yes:

HOU GANG NEW TOWN
(Particulars)


    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development if he will elaborate on the development of Hou Gang New Town; amongst the shopping and other amenities, how many flats will be built; what is the expected population; when the New Town will be completed: and how many constituencies will be involved.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, Hou Gang New Town falls within the constituencies of Paya Lebar and Punggol. When completely developed in 1986-87, it will have a population of 130,000 people housed in 26,000 units of flats. These include 3,000 existing flats in Punggol Estate which will form part of the New Town.

    Hou Gang New Town will be divided into four neighbourhoods, each with its own neighbourhood centre. In addition, a sports complex, schools and other amenities will be provided.

    Approximately 4,700 dwelling units, 140 shops and eating houses and a market-cum-cooked food centre are presently under construction.

     Mr C.V. Devan Nair (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that for Singaporeans who do not understand Hanyu Pinyin, the name of the new town which reads "Hou Gang New Town" could mislead some Singaporeans into believing that it is a new town of gangsters headed by our Hon. Minister of Defence who is also called "Howe".

NEW PUNGGOL FISHING PORT AND MARKET
(Building of)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development, now that the land

Column: 303

on which Kangkar Fish Market stands has been compulsorily acquired, when and where the new fish market in Punggol will be built and what is the cost of construction.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the new Punggol Fishing Port and Market will be built on a 3-hectare site located at the North-eastern coast, opposite Coney Island. The project, which is scheduled to be completed in 1982/83, is estimated to cost more than $5 million.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Raising of income ceiling)


    8. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the fact that the income of Singapore workers has considerably increased in the last decade, whether he will now consider revising upward the combined family income ceiling of $500 to a more realistic figure so that those who earn more than $500 a month will be able to rent two-room flats or to transfer from one-room to two-room flats.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the income ceiling for rental flats is under constant review. The present ceiling of $500 per month has already been relaxed for two groups of applicants. First, existing tenants who have occupied their present flats for at least two years may be allowed a transfer to a 2-room flat, even if the family income exceeds $500 per month. Secondly, resettlement cases in urgent need of accommodation are allowed to rent a flat, even if their income exceeds the income ceiling. However, because of a shortage of 2-room flats, the HDB is unable to allow other public applicants with a family income exceeding $500 per month to be allocated such flats.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, the Minister seems to favour the higher income bracket applicants. The income ceiling for the HUDC applicants has been revised upwards. If he allows this revision, why can the Minister not do the same for the lower income wage earners?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, that is not so because the income limit for rental flats has

Column: 304

been fixed at $800 per month. We have not revised this ceiling for the simple reason that we want to encourage,people to own their own homes. If we allow the ceiling for rental flats to be adjusted upwards, then some people may prefer to rent rather than buy their flats. The ceiling of $800 per month has not been revised for a long time because it is our policy to encourage people to own their own homes.

    As hon. Members are aware, the income ceiling for ownership of HDB flats has been constantly adjusted upwards, that is, from $800 to $1,200; from $1,200 to $1,500, and recently from $1,500 to $2,500. Most probably we may have to further adjust upwards to catch up with inflation and the increase in the price of HDB flats.

HUDC APARTMENTS
(Ownership by single persons)


    9. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for National Development what specific surveys were done and what evidence was obtained to indicate that ownership of Housing and Urban Development Company (HUDC) apartments by single persons should be curbed in view of its "disturbing and undesirable trend".

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Urban Development Company regularly analyses the data it collects on applicants at the time of registration.

    As at 31st January, 1981, HUDC had a waiting list of 6,256 applications. About 46% of the applications were from single persons. An analysis of the characteristics of single-person applicants revealed that 72% earned less than $2,500 per month at the time of registration. The majority are young. About 29% are below 25 years old. Another 51% are between 26 and 30 years old. Most single-person applicants indicated their intention to live alone. 1,981 applicants or 69% of single applicants listed only one occupant.

    There is a rising trend of single persons applying to the HUDC for housing. In 1977,

Column: 305

the number of applications from single persons was only 209. This figure rose to 1,451 in 1980, an increase of almost seven times in three years.

    The Government believes in preserving the family unit to promote social cohesion. Many HDB policies have been revised to encourage families to live together so that the children can take care of their parents. The rising number of young single persons wanting to live on their own is, therefore, an undesirable trend. We do not wish to encourage this trend by making it easy for single persons to obtain HUDC flats.

(Water seepage at gable-end walls)

HDB RESIDENTIAL FLATS
(Shortening of waiting period)


    11. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for National Development (a) what are the current waiting periods for the purchase of the different types of Housing and Development Board residential accommodation and what steps have been taken to shorten them; and (b) whether he will consider working out a scheme whereby applicants on the waiting list may opt to commence paying prior to allocation so that they will not be affected by any price increase.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir:

Column: 306



    (a) the current average waiting period for the purchase of HDB flats is three years, against the normal waiting period of 21/2 years. The longer waiting period has been caused by the recent slowdown in the HDB construction programme. The slowdown has been primarily due to the smaller number of HDB contractors tendering for jobs because of losses incurred in past projects as a result of high inflation. They are also refraining from tendering because of the uncertainties of rising costs.

    The HDB on its part is taking steps to ensure the availability of basic building materials, such as sand, granite and bricks. The HDB is also studying possible modifications of its contracting system, such as cost-plus tendering, to encourage more contractors to tender for projects.

    (b) There are no advantages in having a scheme to allow applicants to pay for their flats prior to allocation. The selling prices of HDB flats have to be revised periodically to meet rising construction costs. Otherwise, the subsidy for public housing will reach unacceptably high proportions. Costs invariably rise during construction because of escalation clauses in building contracts. If applicants pay for their flats before allocation, the HDB will have to provide for builtin allowances for price escalation during the construction period. Applicants will, therefore, not necessarily pay less by paying earlier.

SURCHARGE ON PUB BILLS


    13. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister f6r Health whether he will review the policy of the Public Utilities Board in imposing a 50-cent fine on consumers for the late payment of water and electricity bills as such payment can be a further burden on those who are already unable to pay their bills on time because of financial hardship.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Health (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, imposing a charge of 50c serves as a deterrent against late payment. Since the introduction of the service charge in 1975, the number of reminders has been declining. The proportion of consumers receiving reminders has dropped from 27% to 14%. If the PUB sends reminders without any service charge, consumers will not take the reminders seriously. The charge of 50c barely covers cost. The direct cost (stamp, paper, printing, computer time) of each reminder is 20c. This excludes indirect and overhead costs, and interest lost on late payment. If the proportion of consumers receiving reminders goes up from the present 14%, we may even have to consider imposing a heavier deterrent for late payment.

    If the consumer pays his bill promptly, he will save 50c, and the PUB inconvenience and expenditure.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is a very ridiculous answer. I would like to ask the Minister concerned whether he can do business without having capital or without incurring expenditure.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, I do not quite comprehend the Member for Khe Bong's question.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, when someone does business, he needs to have capital. The PUB expects to do business without even wanting to pay for the printing cost of the reminders. So how could that be possible?

Column: 308



     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, it costs the PUB about $200,000 per year just to send out reminders, and this cost has to be recovered from those consumers who need such reminders.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he has taken into consideration the consumer's deposit of 1 1/2 months' charges for water and electricity. The consumer does not owe the PUB anything because he has got 1 1/2 months' deposit with the PUB.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Sir, I think the Member for Khe Bong has misunderstood the purpose of the deposit. The consumer has, in fact, consumed water and electricity and has not paid the bill for about six weeks. The deposit, therefore, is to ensure that the consumption by the consumer, which is billed six weeks later, will be paid. It is not a pre-payment. The Member appears to have understood that the deposit is a pre-payment for consumption. It is not so.

SUBSIDY FOR ELECTRICITY
AND WATER CHARGES


    14. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Health what is the exact quantum of subsidy paid by Government for a unit block of electricity and water consumed by industries and the household and how does this element of subsidy in Singapore compare with subsidies in other countries.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Government does not subsidize electricity and water charges. Let me explain why we adopt such a policy.

    We import all our oil to generate electricity. The oil producers do not subsidize us. We have to pay the full cost of oil we import. If we subsidize consumers of electricity, we may also have to subsidize bus fares and other services which depend on oil. Where do we find money to pay for these subsidies? The Singapore Government does not print money. If we need more money, we have to raise it through taxes, which means that

Column: 309

ultimately it is the people themselves who have to pay for subsidies, not the Government.

    Another reason: if consumers do not pay the full price of utilities, they will inevitably over-consume. In other words, it is possible for them to live beyond their incomes in actual terms, since part of their consumption is subsidized.

    If we all live beyond our actual capacity to earn incomes, we shall soon find ourselves unable to pay for the full market price of oil. If utilities are not subsidized, we do not have to fear that we are unable to pay for the cost of importing oil because for every barrel of oil we import, the full cost is recovered from the consumers.

    The same arguments against subsidy apply to water.

TAX CONCESSIONS

(i) Separate Assessment on Unearned Incomes of Married Women

    Option for separate assessment on earned incomes was first given to married women in 1963. It is clear today that many married women are capable of deriving unearned incomes in their own right. This, however, has not been given due recognition by our tax laws and I propose to amend it to reflect the current income position of married women. From the Year of Assessment 1982, all

Column: 348

married women who can satisfy the Comptroller of Income Tax that their unearned incomes are derived from their own earned incomes in the past shall be allowed to have these unearned incomes assessed in their names.

    This will reduce the combined tax burden of husbands and wives. It should encourage married women to remain in the workforce, particularly those with tertiary or professional qualifications.

    The loss in revenue is estimated at $3 million.

(ii) Relief for Disabled Persons

    This is the International Year of Disabled Persons. As our contribution, I am increasing the earned income relief for handicapped persons from $1,000 to $2,000. This is in recognition of the contribution of disabled persons in our workforce and to encourage more active participation from our disabled population. This relief will take effect from Year of Assessment 1982.

(iii) Personal Income Tax Rates

    I have in my Budget Statement last year stressed the importance of spreading the income tax net to cover as many individuals as possible. Let me reiterate the reason for this. The more citizens. we have paying income tax, the greater will be the appreciation amongst Singaporeans of the basic fact of life - how to finance various programmes, like health, housing and social welfare. Our people will have a keener understanding that more expenditure on welfare programmes and subsidies must mean an increase in their income tax.

    Those who have to pay income tax to meet the costs of welfare programmes will at once ask themselves why they must work to subsidize the laggards and the indolent who are able-bodied but reluctant to work.

    I am pleased to inform the House that there was an increase in the past year of 91,868 taxpayers. This is a threefold increase over the number of new taxpayers in 1979. They include new entrants to the labour

force, hawkers and taxi-drivers, self-employed .individuals and others who have previously evaded tax.

    As at 31st December, 1980, there were 481,255 individual taxpayers which is 45% of the employed labour force. The overwhelming majority are wage-earners who cannot evade tax. Because of the nature of Singapore's society where the many self-employed can evade tax, income tax has been an inequitable tax borne largely by wage-earners and those professionals who are paid by customers or clients who report their payments to claim tax deduction. Other professionals not paid by corporations behave like taxi-drivers and hawkers in evading income tax.

    It may be many years yet before we bring all the evaders within the tax net; but this is an exercise that the Inland Revenue Department is vigorously pursuing. The Inland Revenue Department is studying the possibility of presumptive taxation of hawkers, restauranteurs, taxi-drivers, property brokers and other free-lancing commercial intermediaries who do not keep proper accounts. Under this scheme, the Department will take sample investigative surveys to determine what these groups are earning. All those in these groups will be deemed to have chargeable incomes based on the findings. The onus of proof will then be on them; it is up to any one of them, hawkers, restauranteurs, property brokers, etc, to rebut presumed taxable income by accounts which show his true income to be lower.

    We are now restructuring our economy. For this to succeed, we must make it worthwhile for workers, especially the young, to spend time and effort in acquiring skills and knowledge. They will find it worthwhile if they can earn more and retain more of their incomes. A worker's effort must not be penalized through too steep a tax. While tax rates must be progressive and linked to ability to pay in order to lighten the burden on the lower income groups, they must never be so high as to suppress the will to strive and to

To take account of the pernicious effect of inflation on tax burdens, and to give Singaporeans further incentive for their effort, I propose to give a tax rebate of 10% to every resident taxpayer on his total tax liability. In other words, if a resident taxpayer is assessed to have a tax liability of $5,000 on the existing rates, he will be given a tax rebate of $500 or 10% of his assessed tax. If his tax liability is $300, he will get a tax rebate of $30.

These are the groups whose chargeable incomes generally fall within $5,000 and $75,000. They will enjoy the largest reduction in tax in percentage terms, a reduction ranging from 17.8% to 25.9%.

To do so is to blunt the spur to excel, to outperform one's peers, the very basis of our vigorous growth. Singaporeans must be encouraged to aspire to higher incomes, through acquisition of higher skills and more knowledge, and their diligent appli-

    Everyone must be encouraged to enlarge his contribution to the national economy. Only then will there be bigger and bigger rewards for all. Then even the semi-skilled will enjoy higher wages because they are part of the total effort.

(iv) Estate Duty

    Members may recall that in the 1979 Budget, an additional exemption of up to $200,000 was granted in respect of residential houses in an estate. This is in addition to the $100,000 exemption which is granted for assets other than residential properties.

    To ensure that the concession continues to give relief to beneficiaries in the lower and middle income groups, I am raising the exemption ceiling for residential properties from $200,000 to $600,000. This is to take account of the rise in property prices in the last two years and to protect the dependants of the deceased who might otherwise have to dispose of their family homes to pay estate duties.

    The new exemption ceiling will apply to all deaths occurring on or after 1st January, 1981. The loss in revenue is estimated at $23 million.

Concluding Remarks

    The tax changes this year is a continuation of the liberalization of the tax system begun in FY 1978, when the Minister for Finance reduced personal income tax rates substantially. Further changes in the tax system, including income tax, may be expected in the next two or three years. We shall adjust our tax regime as income patterns change, as spending habits change, and as investment behaviour changes. Our taxes are designed not to punish effort both collective and individual effort. They are also designed to encourage investments in order that we can enjoy a more productive future.

    Business enterprises have been encouraged to invest and expand through various tax concessions introduced in

Column: 353

previous Budgets, e.g. realistic capital allowances for plant and machinery, equipment and other assets, rationalization of stamp duties, investment allowances and incentives to encourage research and development.

    Individuals are encouraged to excel through periodical adjustment of the income tax rates to take into account inflation and growth in the economy.

    It is our ability to enlarge the economy through intelligent hard work that allows us to reduce tax rates even as Government expenditure increases. We must, however, not be complacent. It is a mistake to believe that we will continue to clear hurdles easily just because we have won a few races in the past. We will not, unless we take each hurdle seriously and make adequate preparations before we come to the obstacles. We must press on vigorously with our economic restructuring. We must bring about a qualitative change in economic activities by the end of this decade.

    We must work together to enlarge our national income. Workers must pull together with management to attain corporate objectives. Management must look after the interests of the workers. They must have an easy relationship of trust, one as between partners in a common endeavour. Our major task in this decade is to inculcate new work attitudes and establish this close working relationship. The Government will motivate and reward. Enterprises and individuals who excel will be rewarded accordingly.

    Economic growth, desirable as it is, is not an end in itself. It is the means which enables us to forge the kind of society we want.. Singaporeans are not homogeneous. There was no quality control in our past immigration policies. Nevertheless, we have succeeded in getting the different races together, to build up a team spirit instead of dissipating our energies in quarrels, jealousies and strife. We must build on this strong foundation.

    We want to have a stable and durable society built on tolerance and equality of opportunities. We want to be a self-respecting, self-reliant people, free of poverty, free of bigotry, free of communal, religious, linguistic and other social tensions.

    The building brick of our structure is the family unit, closely knit by abiding ties of mutual love and mutual support. Without these strong bricks, each bonded to another by lasting ties of mutual respect and trust, the whole structure of our society will crumble under its own weight of intolerance, divisiveness and strife.
